content: The Act may be cited as the "Diabetes Treatment and Prevention Act of 2007". It includes findings related to diabetes. The Diabetes Treatment and Prevention Act of 2007 cites findings on the increasing prevalence of diabetes in the United States. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the number of people living with diabetes has doubled in the past 25 years. The American Diabetes Association reports over 20 million Americans have diabetes, with 6 million undiagnosed cases. Additionally, 54 million have pre-diabetes, putting them at risk for developing diabetes. Lifestyle changes like diet and exercise can help prevent or delay type 2 diabetes, as shown in the Diabetes Prevention Program study of 2002. Participants who made lifestyle changes reduced their risk of type 2 diabetes by 58 percent. Despite successful outcomes, sustainable interventions are lacking. Insurance companies cover diabetes complications but not cheaper prevention methods. Direct medical expenditures for diabetes in 2002 totaled $91.8 billion, with a significant portion directed towards diabetes care and chronic complications. The need to increase availability of community-based lifestyle programs for diabetes prevention and encourage replication of successful programs like the Diabetes Prevention Program on a wider scale to reduce costs associated with diabetes treatment in the United States. SEC. 3. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Division of Diabetes Translation; Diabetes Demonstration Projects. Amends Title III of the Public Health Service Act to include a new section 317T for the CDC Division of Diabetes Translation. The Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will establish a Division of Diabetes Translation to address diabetes prevention and control. The division will conduct surveillance, research, work with states on prevention programs, coordinate education programs, and raise awareness about diabetes. The Division of Diabetes Translation will receive $90,000,000 for fiscal year 2008, with additional funding as needed for subsequent years. "SEC. 317U. DEMONSTRATION PROJECTS FOR IDENTIFICATION AND TREATMENT OF DIABETES." The Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will develop pilot projects to screen and identify individuals at high risk for Type 2 diabetes and provide them with lifestyle interventions. The Director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will develop pilot projects in partnership with academic centers and public health departments to implement lifestyle interventions aimed at reducing the incidence of type 2 diabetes and its complications in the United States population. The Director will require information on the risk and screening methods for targeted populations in the cooperative agreements awarded for a 2-year period, extendable for an additional 2 years. An evaluation report is due to the Committee on Energy and not later than 4 years after the enactment of the Diabetes Treatment and Prevention Act of 2007. The Director will submit a report to the House and Senate committees evaluating the program's effectiveness and authorizing $10,000,000 for fiscal years 2008 through 2012. The Secretary will engage in partnerships with State and local health departments for surveillance and education activities. The Secretary will conduct surveillance on diabetes risk factors, screenings, enrollment in lifestyle programs for pre-diabetes, availability of interventions, and population access to interventions. The Secretary will conduct surveillance on diabetes risk factors, screenings, enrollment in lifestyle programs for pre-diabetes, availability of interventions, and population access to interventions. Additionally, there are authorized appropriations of $10,000,000 for education and information campaigns to increase awareness about diabetes prevention among high-risk populations, healthcare providers, and the general public. The Director will develop a pilot program to improve treatment for individuals with diabetes and other chronic conditions. Cooperative agreements and technical assistance will be provided to academic centers to implement the program. State and local health departments will implement programs to improve health outcomes for individuals with diabetes and other chronic conditions. Applicants must submit an application containing information on the co-occurring conditions to be studied. Preference will be given to research focusing on conditions with high prevalence among individuals with diabetes. The Diabetes Treatment and Prevention Act of 2007 awards cooperative agreements for a 2-year period, extendable for an additional 2 years. A report evaluating the program's effectiveness must be submitted within 4 years of the enactment date. The program under this subsection aims to improve health care outcomes for individuals with diabetes and other chronic conditions. $10,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2008 to 2012.
